name: Harvest and Thankfulness
subject: Religious Studies
pedagogical_rationale: Harvest is the most common RS starting point at KS1 because it connects to children's immediate experience (food, nature, seasons) while introducing the concept of thankfulness across multiple religious traditions. Christianity (Harvest Festival), Judaism (Sukkot), and Hinduism (Pongal) all celebrate harvest, providing natural cross-religious comparison at an accessible level.
common_pitfalls: Reducing harvest to craft activities without the religious dimension
Only covering Christian harvest -- use at least two traditions
Assuming all families celebrate harvest -- some have no religious connection to it

name: Special Books and Sacred Texts
subject: Religious Studies
pedagogical_rationale: Introducing sacred texts at KS1 teaches that some books are considered special or holy by religious communities. Comparing how different religions treat their sacred texts (the Bible, the Torah, the Quran, the Guru Granth Sahib) teaches respect for difference while establishing that religion involves texts, stories, and teachings that guide behaviour.
common_pitfalls: Handling sacred texts carelessly -- model how each tradition treats its text with respect
Only reading Bible stories -- include at least two different traditions
Presenting sacred texts as 'fairy tales' -- teach that believers consider them deeply meaningful

name: Why Do People Pray?
subject: Religious Studies
pedagogical_rationale: Prayer is a practice common to most religions but expressed in radically different ways. Comparing Christian prayer (individual, communal, Lord's Prayer), Islamic salah (five daily prayers with ritual washing and specific movements), and Hindu puja (worship with images, incense, and offerings) teaches that the same human impulse (communicating with the divine) produces diverse practices shaped by different beliefs.
common_pitfalls: Presenting prayer as just 'talking to God' -- many prayer traditions involve specific bodily practices
Only covering Christian prayer -- the comparison is the learning
Making children pray -- RS teaches about prayer, it does not require participation

name: What Makes a Good Leader?
subject: Religious Studies
pedagogical_rationale: Studying religious leaders (Jesus, Muhammad, Guru Nanak, the Buddha, Moses) through the lens of leadership teaches both theological content and ethical reasoning. Pupils compare what makes a good leader across traditions: compassion, justice, courage, wisdom. This connects to PSHE (leadership in school) and History (historical leaders).
common_pitfalls: Treating religious figures as historical characters only -- they are objects of devotion for believers
Ranking leaders as 'best' -- the comparison should highlight different qualities, not create a hierarchy
Only covering male leaders -- include Miriam, Khadijah, Mirabai where appropriate

name: Christian Beliefs: The Nature of God
subject: Religious Studies
curriculum_reference: demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the beliefs, teachings and practices of at least two religions
pedagogical_rationale: The nature of God (omnipotent, omniscient, omnibenevolent, Trinity) is the foundational theological topic for GCSE RS. Understanding these attributes and the philosophical tensions between them (the Problem of Evil: if God is all-powerful and all-loving, why does suffering exist?) develops the analytical and evaluative skills required for exam success.
common_pitfalls: Students memorise attributes without understanding the philosophical tensions between them
Problem of Evil discussed superficially -- push for the logical structure of the argument
Not distinguishing Christian views from generic theism

name: Islamic Beliefs: Tawhid and the Six Articles of Faith
subject: Religious Studies
curriculum_reference: demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the beliefs, teachings and practices of at least two religions
pedagogical_rationale: Tawhid (the absolute oneness of God) is the central Islamic belief from which all others flow. Understanding the Six Articles of Faith (belief in God, angels, holy books, prophets, the Day of Judgement, predestination) provides the complete theological framework for GCSE Islam. The Sunni-Shi'a distinction on articles of faith introduces intra-religious diversity.
common_pitfalls: Conflating Sunni and Shi'a beliefs -- the Five Roots of Usul ad-Din differ from the Six Articles
Reducing Islam to the Five Pillars (those are practices, not beliefs)
Not using Arabic terminology -- examiners expect key terms: Tawhid, Risalah, Akhirah
sacred_texts: Quran 2:285 (belief in God, angels, books, messengers)

name: Christian Practices: Worship and Sacraments
subject: Religious Studies
curriculum_reference: demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the key practices, rituals and forms of worship of at least two religions
pedagogical_rationale: Christian worship varies enormously across denominations -- from Catholic Mass with Eucharist to Quaker silent worship. Studying this diversity teaches that Christianity is not monolithic and that the same beliefs produce different practices depending on tradition, interpretation, and emphasis. The sacraments (particularly baptism and Eucharist) demonstrate how theology is enacted in ritual.
common_pitfalls: Only covering one denomination -- the comparison between Catholic, Protestant, and Orthodox practices is essential
Describing rituals without explaining their theological meaning
Students confusing 'sacrament' with 'ceremony' -- sacraments have specific theological significance

name: Medical Ethics: Euthanasia
subject: Religious Studies
curriculum_reference: analyse and evaluate ethical issues from religious and secular perspectives, constructing well-reasoned arguments
pedagogical_rationale: Euthanasia is a mandatory thematic study that requires pupils to evaluate competing ethical frameworks. It tests the ability to construct sustained, balanced arguments using both religious teachings (sanctity of life, sovereignty of God, compassion) and secular ethical theories (autonomy, utilitarianism, natural law). The topic generates genuine moral engagement because pupils recognise it as a real-world dilemma.
common_pitfalls: Students stating opinions without evidence -- insist on textual/philosophical support for every claim
Only covering 'for and against' -- nuance requires distinguishing voluntary, non-voluntary, active, passive
Emotional reactions replacing analytical thinking -- validate feelings but redirect to argument

name: Crime and Punishment
subject: Religious Studies
curriculum_reference: analyse and evaluate ethical issues from religious and secular perspectives, constructing well-reasoned arguments
pedagogical_rationale: Crime and Punishment covers the aims of punishment (retribution, deterrence, reformation, protection), the death penalty, forgiveness, and the treatment of criminals. It connects to Citizenship (law and justice) and provides rich material for evaluative writing. Religious perspectives on forgiveness (Christianity) and justice (Islam) are central to the exam.
common_pitfalls: Students defaulting to 'eye for an eye' without analysing alternatives
Not distinguishing the aims of punishment -- retribution and deterrence are fundamentally different philosophies
Death penalty discussion becoming US-focused -- include UK abolition history and Islamic perspectives
sacred_texts: Quran 5:45 (life for life, eye for eye)

name: Religion and Science
subject: Religious Studies
curriculum_reference: analyse and evaluate ethical issues from religious and secular perspectives, constructing well-reasoned arguments
pedagogical_rationale: The religion-science relationship is perennially engaging for KS4 pupils. The creation vs evolution debate is the entry point, but the deeper learning is about the nature of different truth claims: scientific truth (empirical, testable, provisional) vs religious truth (revealed, faith-based, absolute). Understanding that many scientists are religious, and many religious people accept evolution, prevents the false binary.
common_pitfalls: Presenting it as religion vs science -- many traditions see no conflict
Only covering creationism -- include intelligent design, theistic evolution, and day-age interpretations
Students picking a 'side' without understanding the nuances of each position
